title: Android Auto
text:
Android Auto is a <a href="mobile%20app">mobile app</a> developed by <a href="Google">Google</a> to mirror features of an <a href="Android%20%28operating%20system%29">Android</a> device, such as a <a href="smartphone">smartphone</a>, on a car's dashboard information and entertainment <a href="head%20unit">head unit</a>.
Once an Android device is paired with the car's head unit, the system can mirror some apps on the vehicle's display. Supported apps include <a href="GPS">GPS</a> <a href="Web%20mapping">mapping</a> and <a href="Automotive%20navigation%20system">navigation</a>, music playback, <a href="Short%20Message%20Service">SMS</a>, telephone, and <a href="Web%20search%20engine">Web search</a>. The system supports both touchscreen and button-controlled head units. Hands-free operation through <a href="Speech%20recognition">voice commands</a> is available and recommended to reduce driver distraction.
Android Auto is part of the <a href="Open%20Automotive%20Alliance">Open Automotive Alliance</a>, a joint effort of 28 automobile manufacturers, with <a href="Nvidia">Nvidia</a> as tech supplier, available in 36 countries.
Functionality.
The most common way Android Auto is deployed is via an <a href="Android%20%28operating%20system%29">Android</a> <a href="mobile%20device">mobile device</a> running the Android Auto app, acting as a master to a vehicle's dashboard <a href="head%20unit">head unit</a> that supports this functionality. Once the user's Android device is connected to the vehicle, the head unit will serve as an external display for the Android device, presenting supported software in a car-specific <a href="user%20interface">user interface</a> provided by the Android Auto app. In Android Auto's first iterations, the device was required to be connected via USB to the car.
Alternatively, in November 2016, Google added the option to run Android Auto as a regular app on an Android device, i.e., not tethered to a car's head unit, which allows it to be used on Android-powered head units, or simply on a personal phone or tablet in the vehicle.
Availability.
, Android Auto is available in 44 countries:
App support.
An Android Auto <a href="software%20development%20kit">SDK</a> has been released, allowing third parties to modify their apps to work with Android Auto; initially, only <a href="Application%20programming%20interface">API</a>s for music and messaging apps are available.
At <a href="CES%202018">CES 2018</a>, Google confirmed that the <a href="Google%20Assistant">Google Assistant</a> would be coming to Android Auto later in the year.
Currently supported apps include <a href="Google%20Maps%20%28application%29">Google Maps</a> and <a href="Waze">Waze</a>, popular music players such as <a href="Google%20Play%20Music">Google Play Music</a>, <a href="YouTube%20Music">YouTube Music</a>, <a href="Amazon%20Music">Amazon Music</a>, <a href="Apple%20Music">Apple Music</a> and <a href="Spotify">Spotify</a>; and messaging apps, including <a href="WhatsApp">WhatsApp</a>, <a href="Facebook%20Messenger">Facebook Messenger</a>, <a href="Google%20Hangouts">Google Hangouts</a>, <a href="Skype">Skype</a> and <a href="Telegram%20%28messaging%20service%29">Telegram</a>.
Head unit support.
In May 2015, <a href="Hyundai%20Motor%20Company">Hyundai</a> became the first manufacturer to offer Android Auto support, making it first available in the 2015 <a href="Hyundai%20Sonata">Hyundai Sonata</a>. Automobile manufacturers that will offer Android Auto support in their cars include <a href="Abarth">Abarth</a>, <a href="Acura">Acura</a>, <a href="Alfa%20Romeo">Alfa Romeo</a>, <a href="Audi">Audi</a>, <a href="Bentley">Bentley</a>, <a href="Buick">Buick</a>, <a href="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="Cadillac">Cadillac</a>, <a href="Chevrolet">Chevrolet</a>, <a href="Chrysler">Chrysler</a>, <a href="Citro%C3%ABn">Citroën</a>, <a href="Dodge">Dodge</a>, <a href="Ferrari">Ferrari</a>, <a href="Fiat">Fiat</a>, <a href="Ford%20Motor%20Company">Ford</a>, <a href="GMC%20%28automobile%29">GMC</a>, <a href="Genesis%20Motors">Genesis</a>, <a href="Holden">Holden</a>, <a href="Honda">Honda</a>, <a href="Hyundai%20Motor%20Company">Hyundai</a>, <a href="Infiniti">Infiniti</a>, <a href="Jaguar%20Land%20Rover">Jaguar Land Rover</a>, <a href="Jeep">Jeep</a>, <a href="Kia%20Motors">Kia</a>, <a href="Lamborghini">Lamborghini</a>, <a href="Lexus">Lexus</a>, <a href="Lincoln%20Motor%20Company">Lincoln</a>, <a href="Mahindra%20and%20Mahindra">Mahindra and Mahindra</a>, <a href="Maserati">Maserati</a>, <a href="Mazda">Mazda</a>, <a href="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a>, <a href="Mitsubishi">Mitsubishi</a>, <a href="Nissan">Nissan</a>, <a href="Opel">Opel</a>, <a href="Peugeot">Peugeot</a>, <a href="Porsche">Porsche</a>, <a href="RAM%20trucks">RAM</a>, <a href="Renault">Renault</a>, <a href="SEAT">SEAT</a>, <a href="%C5%A0koda%20Auto">Škoda</a>, <a href="SsangYong%20Motor">SsangYong</a>, <a href="Subaru">Subaru</a>, <a href="Suzuki">Suzuki</a>, <a href="Tata%20Motors%20Cars">Tata Motors Cars</a>, <a href="Toyota">Toyota</a>, <a href="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a> and <a href="Volvo">Volvo</a>.
Additionally, aftermarket car-audio systems supporting Android Auto add the technology into host vehicles, including Pioneer, Kenwood, Panasonic, and Sony.
Criticism.
In May 2019, <a href="Italy">Italy</a> filed an antitrust complaint targeting Android Auto, citing that a Google policy of only allowing third-party media and messaging apps on the platform prevented <a href="Enel">Enel</a> from offering an app for locating vehicle <a href="charging%20stations">charging stations</a>.
Initially, Google did not enable third parties to integrate their mapping apps with Android Auto, only its own apps, Google Maps and Waze, being available. But since 2020, third party mapping apps such as Sygic are also available. 
Google announced a new SDK to be released to select partners in August 2020 and to be generally available by the end of 2020.
